We first define following predicates and corresponding natural language explanations:
Furry($x, bool) ::: Is x furry?
Nice($x, bool) ::: Is x nice?
Smart($x, bool) ::: Is x smart?
Young($x, bool) ::: Is x young?
Green($x, bool) ::: Is x green?
Big($x, bool) ::: Is x big?
Round($x, bool) ::: Is x round?
We have following known facts from the context:
Furry(Anne, True) ::: Anne is furry.
Nice(Anne, True) ::: Anne is nice.
Smart(Anne, True) ::: Anne is smart.
Young(Bob, True) ::: Bob is young.
Nice(Erin, True) ::: Erin is nice.
Smart(Harry, True) ::: Harry is smart.
Young(Harry, True) ::: Harry is young.
We have following known rules from the context:
rule1: Young($x, True) >>> Furry($x, True) ::: Young things are furry.
rule2: Nice($x, True) && Furry($x, True) >>> Green($x, True) ::: Nice, furry things are green.
rule3: Green($x, True) >>> Nice($x, True) ::: All green things are nice.
rule4: Nice($x, True) && Green($x, True) >>> Big($x, True) ::: Nice, green things are big.
rule5: Green($x, True) >>> Smart($x, True) ::: All green things are smart.
rule6: Big($x, True) && Young($x, True) >>> Round($x, True) ::: If something is big and young then it is round.
rule7: Green($x, True) >>> Big($x, True) ::: All green things are big.
rule8: Young(Harry, True) >>> Furry(Harry, True) ::: If Harry is young then Harry is furry.
rule9: Furry($x, True) && Smart($x, True) >>> Nice($x, True) ::: Furry, smart things are nice.
Now begin reasoning to obtain all implied facts:

Bind $x to 'Bob'
Obtain an already known or implied fact: Young('Bob', True)
Obtain a new implied fact: Furry('Bob', True)
Unbind $x
Finish implied with rule1
Reuse rule1: Young($x, True) >>> Furry($x, True)
Bind $x to 'Harry'
